Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2010 04:28PM Macc wrote: You usually lay on your back (occasionally on the front with your boob dangling thro a gap depending on the type of machine). Google radiotherapy and click on images at the top when the results pop up. You'll see a picture of someone lying under a machine. The staff will need to either draw lines on you or put small tatooed dots so that the machine can align itself correctly. After the first exam by the rad onc no one should need to manhandle your boob  unless you have a problem. Mine is a bit sore inside after 25 sessions and the rad onc did prod it abit today. The staff could be men or women I guess. Mine were women altho there was a male trainee for the last 3 weeks. I don't think you should be manhandled too much by anyone there....certainly not compared to a followup with the surgeon who usually does a good bit of manhandling in the whole area. I hope it all goes well and try not to worry too much about it. I know it's easier said than done, but I hope we have reduced your concerns abit. All the best, Macc

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2010 05:36PM Macc wrote: I did 4 AC and then 4 TH with Herceptin on my first T. Everyone reacts differently as you no doubt know already but I was glad not to have the nausea with TH that I had with AC. My bloods also got hit hard with T so I had the immune boosting injection, Neulasta. I suffered Hand and Foot syndrome too which makes your hands and feet go very red and peel, altho I think this is less common. I had some of the nerve damage too which affected my feet more and is almost gone in my hands (last TH mid Nov) but my toes are still a little numb. You  need to see how you are after each treatment. My onc said I could go onto Taxol or lower the does of T if it became an unbearable problem. My nails are peeling...they went very thick and the tops layers have come off to reveal a thin layer underneath. It's more inconvenient than anything as I have to put bandaids on them to stop them catching on everything I touch. For me I don't think that H made much difference. I'm on just that now and I don't have SE's except slow hair growth and I also had a problem with very watery eyes which could have been either T or H or a combination of both together. Steroid drops have almost stopped that now. Some people get bone/joint/muscle pain which I didn't get at all with any of the chemo or H altho I did  get a little with the Neualsta, but it wasn't much really for me anyway. I hope you get on well with TH. I was very anxious beforehand too. Vit B6 is supposed to help prevent nerve damage, so you could mention this to your onc to see if he is happy for you to take it. Good Luck! Macc

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2009 02:23PM Macc wrote: My understanding is that it means the no of different angles which the equipment uses to treat the breast/lymph nodes. Each angle directs the radiation to an area of the breast i.e. a field. This will vary according to whether the lymph nodes need treating and also to the shape of the breast since they try not to overlap the fields. E.G. I am having 4 field radiation and have a dose from each side of the breast which zaps the lymph nodes under the arm too, one to the lymph nodes near the collar bone from the front and one to the same area from the back.  Hope this helps.
